transcript.value: Let’s do something small. Three minutes is enough.
Take a breath. Or don’t. Either is fine.
Notice this: you’re already aware. Something is hearing these words.
You don’t need to create awareness. It’s already here.
Thoughts might show up. Sounds might show up. That’s not a mistake.
If the mind wanders, that’s not a problem. Noticing that it wandered is the practice.
For a few breaths, see if you can recognize awareness — again and again — right in the middle of ordinary experience.
If you feel overwhelmed, open your eyes and feel your feet. You can stop anytime.
Before we finish: notice you practiced by noticing. That counts.

transcript.value: Let’s use the body as a simple anchor.
You can keep your eyes open or closed — whichever feels safer.
Notice contact: feet on the floor, body on the chair.
If you can feel the breath, great. If not, use hands, feet, or warmth in the face.
If the mind wanders, that’s normal. Gently return to one physical sensation.
If anything feels too intense, open your eyes and look around. That’s still practice.
To finish, notice: you can feel sensation and be aware at the same time.

transcript.value: This isn’t about forcing positivity. It’s about practicing a gentler relationship with experience.
Start with yourself. If that’s hard, start with ‘someone like you’ — a human trying to get through the day.
Quietly offer a simple wish: ‘May I have a little more ease.’
If it feels fake, that’s okay. Notice what you feel — numb, warm, resistant — and let that be included.
Now widen slightly: ‘May others have a little more ease too.’ No need to picture anyone clearly.
To finish, notice the intention itself. The practice is the willingness to be kind.

sessions.title: Open Awareness (8 min) — Let experience unfold

transcript.value: In this practice, there’s no single object.
Let sounds, thoughts, and sensations come and go.
Your job is not to manage the mind. It’s to notice awareness as things change.
If you feel overwhelmed, return to a body anchor: feet, hands, or breath.
You might notice moments of space. You might not. Either is fine.
To finish, notice: awareness is still here, even with a busy mind.
